flow.context: Rick Elliott is the President/Owner of Elliott Beach Rentals — a legacy Myrtle Beach vacation rental and property management operation running since 1959 under the Elliott Realty umbrella. He is the ultimate decision-maker on budget, brand direction, and vendor relationships across what appears to be a large portfolio with in-house housekeeping and maintenance teams and multiple offices in North Myrtle Beach and Myrtle Beach. No inspection photo platform was found in their tech stack. His COO Brandon Cox (tenured since 2008, promoted to COO Jan 2024) is the natural referral if Rick delegates operations-level conversations; Kyle Thomas is Guest Services Manager. Strongest angle for Sam: East Coast PM traction as social proof and the reputation-protection frame for a sixty-plus-year-old brand — call the main office at 843-273-1223 and ask for Rick if no direct line is available.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Rick — I've been working with a couple other vacation rental companies out on the East Coast, and honestly Elliott Beach keeps coming up as one of the top operators down in Myrtle Beach. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Feet up energy. Smile. Sound like a peer calling a peer, not a vendor pitching a prospect. Let the compliment about Elliott Beach land naturally — he built this brand his whole life.

they_say_no.label: THEY SAY NO
they_say_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I work with a few property management companies on their turnover and inspection workflows. Wanted to run something by you real quick.
they_say_no.note: Self-deprecating laugh then pivot. Don't rush past this — let the pause after 'real quick' do its job. He'll either give you a green light or push back.

they_say_yes.label: THEY SAY YES
they_say_yes.say: Oh nice — well usually we'd be working with somebody like you. What'd you hear?
they_say_yes.note: Rare but great. Let them talk. Whatever they say, bridge into discovery. Do NOT launch into a pitch.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday afternoon?
bad_timing.note: Suggest a specific day and general time. Be breezy about it. If he counters with a different day, take it immediately.

reschedule_set.label: RESCHEDULE LOCKED
reschedule_set.say: Perfect — I'll give you a ring then. Really appreciate it, Rick. Talk soon.
reschedule_set.note: Log the exact callback time in CRM immediately. Do not add anything else — get off the phone.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION ASK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally fair — it is a cold call, I'll be straight with you. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: Honesty disarms. Asking for 30 seconds shows you respect his time. The hang-up line gives him control, which paradoxically makes him more likely to listen.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I just caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: This is your last shot. The 'so nobody bugs you again' line reframes it as doing HIM a favor. The split question reopens the door.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I was talking with another vacation rental company owner — beach market, been around for decades, runs his own housekeeping and maintenance crew in-house — and the thing that kept nagging at him was that his inspectors caught most issues during turnovers. Most. But the stuff that slipped through — a stain on a couch, a cracked tile, a missing remote — that's what showed up in the Google reviews. Guest checks in, finds something that should've been flagged, and suddenly there's a one-star review sitting under a brand he spent his whole career building. And the part that really got him — his team was already taking photos every single turnover. The evidence was right there in their system. Nobody just had the bandwidth to go through every shot across every property.
pain_trigger.note: STOP TALKING after this. Let the silence sit. Rick has spent decades building Elliott Beach Rentals — the reputation angle will hit. Do not rush into the solution. Wait for his reaction.

branches.label: What do you do about it?

warm_engaged.label: DISCOVERY — PROCESS
warm_engaged.say: Yeah — I figured that might ring a bell. So I'm curious, Rick — what does your inspection process actually look like right now after a turnover? Is your housekeeping crew taking photos, or do you have separate inspectors, or how does that work?
warm_engaged.note: You are in discovery mode. Stop pitching entirely. Ask and LISTEN. Rick is an owner — he has opinions and he knows his operation. Let him talk.

discovery_scale_season.label: DISCOVERY — SCALE AND SEASON
discovery_scale_season.say: Got it — that makes sense. And with summer coming up, how many turnovers are you guys cranking through in a peak week? I imagine with the Myrtle Beach season it gets pretty wild.
discovery_scale_season.note: Anchor to seasonal pressure. Myrtle Beach peak is June through August. This makes the problem time-sensitive and real. Whatever number he gives, acknowledge it.

branches.label: Shares volume / acknowledges it's a lot

discovery_pain_depth.label: DISCOVERY — DIG DEEPER
discovery_pain_depth.say: Wow, that's a serious volume. So when something does slip through — a guest finds damage that wasn't caught — what does that look like on your end? Is it your guest services team scrambling, or does it come all the way up to you?
discovery_pain_depth.note: This ties the pain to Rick personally. As an owner, guest complaints that hit reviews or cause refunds are his problem. Let him connect the dots himself.

branches.label: Explains the fallout / clearly a pain point
Kyle or guest services handles it

solution_bridge.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
solution_bridge.say: Makes total sense. So real quick — what we built is an AI that plugs into the photos your team's already taking during turnovers and automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues — catches the stuff that's easy to miss when you're doing hundreds of turns a week. No workflow change for your crew. It just reads what they're already capturing.
solution_bridge.note: One breath. Do not oversell. Do not list features. Go straight to CTA after this.

soft_cta.label: SOFT CTA
soft_cta.say: Would you be open to seeing what that actually looks like? Not right now obviously — when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue. I could walk you through what a couple other East Coast property managers are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
soft_cta.note: Low pressure. The value proposition is the meeting itself, not the product. 'Steal some ideas' makes it feel like he wins either way.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Perfect. I've got next week pulled up — how does Tuesday or Wednesday afternoon look? Even fifteen, twenty minutes is plenty.
book_meeting.note: Give two options. Lock a specific day and time. Send the invite while still on the phone if possible.

branches.label: Let me check and get back to you

meeting_locked.label: MEETING CONFIRMED
meeting_locked.say: Done — I'll shoot you a calendar invite right now. Really appreciate you taking my call, Rick. Looking forward to it.
meeting_locked.note: Stop selling immediately. Confirm and get off the phone. Send the calendar invite within 60 seconds of hanging up.

meeting_locked_with_brandon.label: MEETING WITH BRANDON TOO
meeting_locked_with_brandon.say: Love that — I'll include Brandon on the invite too. What's the best email for both of you? I'll send it over right now.
meeting_locked_with_brandon.note: Owner plus COO on the same call is the ideal outcome. Get both email addresses. Don't fumble this by adding more talk.

send_email_request.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email_request.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most useful to include so it's not just another generic pitch sitting in your inbox?
send_email_request.note: Their answer tells you exactly what they care about. Listen carefully and tailor the email to whatever they say.

email_confirm_address.label: CONFIRM EMAIL
email_confirm_address.say: Got it — I'll put something together and get it over to you today. What's the best email? Is it rick at elliottbeachrentals dot com or a different one?
email_confirm_address.note: Confirm the address. Suggest a plausible pattern. Include a specific meeting time suggestion in the email — don't leave it open-ended.

email_sent_end.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED — END
email_sent_end.say: Perfect. I'll have that in your inbox this afternoon. Appreciate your time, Rick — talk soon.
email_sent_end.note: Send the email within the hour. Lead with the specific thing he asked about. End the email with a concrete time suggestion for a 15-minute call.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that inspections just aren't really a pain point for you guys right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? Honestly, I get it either way.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first. Surprise him by not pushing back. The split question keeps the door open without being pushy.

branches.label: Hard no / wants off the phone

split_not_interested_deeper.label: DIG INTO NOT INTERESTED
split_not_interested_deeper.say: That's great — honestly most companies I talk to feel pretty good about it until peak season hits and volume doubles overnight. Look, I'm definitely not trying to sell you anything today. But if you ever wanted to see what other operators in your market are doing with their turnover photos — even just to benchmark — happy to show you. No strings at all.
split_not_interested_deeper.note: Reframe around competitive intelligence. Rick is an owner who has been in this market for decades — he wants to know what the competition is doing. Mentioning 'your market' is intentional.

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it — nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone bring on something new. Just so I know — is it that budget for this year is completely locked down, or is it more that anything new you try to bring in has to go through a whole approval process?
objection_no_budget.note: Agree and split. Don't argue about money. You're learning how their buying process works, which is intel for the follow-up.

branches.label: We're just not spending on this

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with the number of properties you guys manage, you'd have to have something dialed in at this point. Is it that you're fully covered and everything's working great, or is it more that switching or adding anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: Validate what they have. The split reveals whether they're genuinely happy or just change-averse. Both are useful intel.

split_have_process_fine.label: PROCESS WORKS — DIG DEEPER
split_have_process_fine.say: That's awesome — honestly most companies aren't that buttoned up. Out of curiosity, are your inspectors reviewing photos manually after every turn, or have you guys automated any of that?
split_have_process_fine.note: 'Everything's fine' usually has cracks underneath. The manual vs. automated question plants the seed that there's a level above where they are now. Listen carefully.

reframe_pain.label: REFRAME AROUND VOLUME
reframe_pain.say: Got it — and that probably works until volume spikes, right? The companies I work with were in a similar spot. Photos were getting taken every turn, but peak season hits and suddenly you've got a hundred turnovers in a day and nobody's got time to review every shot. That's exactly where stuff slips through. Would it be worth taking fifteen minutes to see how other companies have handled that? Even just as a benchmark.
reframe_pain.note: Tie it back to seasonal volume. Myrtle Beach summers are intense. This reframe makes the pain feel inevitable, not theoretical.

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Look — you're probably not buying anything from a cold call today, and I totally respect that. But when budget does free up or you're planning for next season, the people who move fastest are the ones who already know what's on their list. Would you be open to just taking a look — fifteen minutes, no pitch, just show you what it does — so it's on your radar when the time's right?
sell_test_drive.note: Remove all buying pressure. Future-frame it. The meeting is the only goal. If he still says no, gracefully offer email as a fallback.

delegates_down.label: REFERRAL — DELEGATES TO OPS
delegates_down.say: Totally makes sense — Brandon Cox, right? He's your COO? Would you mind if I reached out to him directly, or would it be better coming from you as a quick intro?
delegates_down.note: Name-drop Brandon to show you've done your homework. A warm intro from the owner is gold — push gently for that. If Rick seems surprised you know Brandon's name, just say 'I saw he runs ops for you guys.'

branches.label: Yeah reach out to Brandon directly

referral_get_contact.label: GET BRANDON'S CONTACT
referral_get_contact.say: Perfect — I really appreciate that. Do you happen to know the best way to get ahold of him? Direct line or email?
referral_get_contact.note: Get whatever you can — email, extension, direct line. Even a confirmed spelling of the email is a win. If he doesn't know, ask if the main office can transfer you.

branches.label: Just call the main number and ask

referral_warm_intro.label: WARM INTRO FROM RICK
referral_warm_intro.say: That would be amazing — I really appreciate it. I can shoot you a quick two-liner to forward his way so it's easy on your end. What's the best email to send that to?
referral_warm_intro.note: This is the best possible referral outcome. Get Rick's email, send a concise forwardable note within the hour. Keep it to 3 sentences max.

branches.label: I'll just mention it to him

referral_ask_other.label: REFERRAL — DIFFERENT PERSON
referral_ask_other.say: Got it — who on your team usually owns the turnover and inspection side of things? Just want to make sure I'm reaching the right person so I'm not wasting anybody's time.
referral_ask_other.note: Get a name and title. Even if it's not Brandon, any named referral from the owner is extremely valuable. If he mentions Kyle Thomas (Guest Services), that's also a strong contact.

branches.label: Not sure / figure it out yourself

referral_confirmed.label: REFERRAL LOCKED
referral_confirmed.say: Really appreciate it, Rick. I'll keep it short and relevant when I reach out — no spam, I promise. Thanks for your time today.
referral_confirmed.note: You got the referral. Stop talking. Follow up within the hour. When you call Brandon, open with 'Rick pointed me your way.'

end_graceful.label: END GRACEFULLY
end_graceful.say: Totally understand, Rick. If anything ever comes up on the inspection or turnover side, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Really appreciate your time.
end_graceful.note: Do not burn this bridge. Be genuine. Log the call, note the outcome, and set a follow-up task for 60-90 days. Rick is the owner — even a 'no' today is useful intel for approaching Brandon separately.
